segment.source: Getting started: Common Controls
segment.target: Getting started: Common Controls

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Common controls list
segment.target: Common controls list

segment.source: In the previous section, you worked with only two controls: buttons and textblocks.
segment.target: In the previous section, you worked with only two controls: buttons and textblocks.

segment.source: There are, of course, many many more controls that are available to you.
segment.target: There are, of course, many many more controls that are available to you.

segment.source: Here are some common controls you'll be using in your apps, and their iOS equivalents.
segment.target: Here are some common controls you'll be using in your apps, and their iOS equivalents.

segment.source: The iOS controls are listed in alphabetical order, next to the most similar Universal Windows Platform (UWP) controls.
segment.target: The iOS controls are listed in alphabetical order, next to the most similar Universal Windows Platform (UWP) controls.

segment.source: The rather clever thing about UWP controls is that they can sense the type of device they are running on, and change their appearance and functionality accordingly.
segment.target: The rather clever thing about UWP controls is that they can sense the type of device they are running on, and change their appearance and functionality accordingly.

segment.source: For example, if your project uses the **DatePicker** control, it is smart enough to optimize itself to look and behave differently on a desktop computer compared to, say, a phone.
segment.target: For example, if your project uses the **DatePicker** control, it is smart enough to optimize itself to look and behave differently on a desktop computer compared to, say, a phone.

segment.source: You don't need to do anything: the controls adjust themselves at run-time.
segment.target: You don't need to do anything: the controls adjust themselves at run-time.
